review.title: Plan-based Policies for Efficient Multiple Battery Load Management
review.abstract: Efficient use of multiple batteries is a practical problem with wide and growing application. The problem can be cast as a planning problem under uncertainty. We describe the approach we have adopted to modelling and solving this problem, seen as a Markov Decision Problem, building effective policies for battery switching in the face of stochastic load profiles.

metadata.title: Plan-based Policies for Efficient Multiple Battery Load Management

sections.text: We describe the approach we have taken to modeling and solving this problem as a Markov decision problem that enables the development of effective strategies for battery replacement in the face of stochastic load profiles. Our solution uses and adapts several existing techniques: planning for deterministic mixed discrete-continuous problems and Monte Carlo random samples for policy learning. The paper describes the development of planning techniques that enable a solution to nonlinear continuous dynamic models for recording battery behavior. This approach depends on carefully managed discrediting of the time dimension. Strategies are developed using a classification approach and this idea offers opportunities for wider use of other problems. The approach and its generality are described in the paper crafting. Application of the approach leads to the construction of strategies that significantly exceed those that are currently in use in the simulation, and the best published solutions for the battery physics problem do not match the 99% accurately with the results obtained in the simulation of the battery physics.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: The paper is an extended and developed version of the work originally presented at the International Conference on Automatic Planning and Planning (Fox, Long, & Magazzeni, 2011) and in particular adds physical results to the work described in this paper. An increasing number of systems depend on the battery supply, ranging from small mobile devices to very large high-performance devices, such as batteries used for local storage in substations. In many of these systems, there are significant user benefits or technical reasons to support the supply of multiple batteries, with the load between batteries being switched by a control system. To operate such systems for the longest time, it is necessary to develop strategies that extract the maximum life of batteries. We show how planning is used as the basis for a highly efficient switching strategy.

sections.heading: 2. Motivations
sections.text: Many electrically powered systems rely on large, heavy batteries to provide an adequate level of power and current. If the power requirements of these devices can be met by multiple lightweight batteries that carry the same load as is normally provided by a much larger battery, this could significantly change the way these devices are used and the range of applications for which they may be suitable. Examples of powered systems that could benefit from the distribution of battery power include externally operated electric prostheses powered by electric motors may be more functional and attractive than body-operated prostheses, but they can be heavy and expensive. The performance requirements of a capable prosthetic arm that combines an elbow with a dexterous hand require a large, and therefore heavy battery. The high-speed motors needed to drive a prosthetic elbow require high voltages and current, while modern skillful hands require significantly more power than traditional motorized hands.

sections.heading: 9. Conclusions
sections.text: This paper has presented an interesting and potentially important problem, the management of systems powered by multiple independent batteries, and has found a novel solution to it. In doing so, we have brought together research on planning and policy learning to arrive at a new and powerful approach. We have evaluated our plans experimentally and learned strategies in simulation, and these results show that our solution can be better than 99% efficiency compared to the theoretical optimum (which is unattainable in practice). Not only do we achieve very high efficiencies, but we do so at a low cost in terms of battery replacement, which is advantageous because switching is energy wasteful and tends to reduce the quality of service without additional smoothing, which leads to energy losses. After confirming our results in the simulation, we explore the behavior of the ideas in physical tests, and these results confirm that the real batteries are far less good than their simulated counterparts.

Again, these problems are similar to ours, although their planner does not manage continuous time-dependent resources, so is not directly applicable to our problem. Furthermore, the largest problems they consider contain 4,000,000 states and take more than an hour to solve. In solving very large MDPs, researchers have identified a variety of techniques that can help to overcome the prohibitive cost of policy iteration or value iteration, the classical techniques for solving MDPs. In general, these techniques approximate the solution, often focussing on those parts of the policy that apply to states that are likely to be visited along the trajectory. Relevant techniques are discussed in the work of Bertsekas and Tsitsiklis (1996). Our approach is in the branch of work devoted to the development of plan-based reasoning under uncertainty.

In that work (Fox et al., 2012), we apply exactly the same policy-learning technique as described here to the problem of learning robust observable-correlate policies for following the boundary of a surface algal bloom.

In this work we used the Kinetic Battery Model (Manwell & McGowan, 1993) and we followed the parameter estimation process described by Manwell and McGowan (1994). Following their description, the extended KiBaM has three parts: a capacity model, a voltage model and a lifetime model.

Manwell and McGowan (1994) have proposed a lifetime model based on a rainflow cyclecounting algorithm which takes into account the fact that recharging damages the batteries and affects their ability to deliver charge.
Our recent work on algal bloom mapping (Fox et al., 2012) indicates the directions we are considering.

metadata.abstractText: Efficient use of multiple batteries is a practical problem with wide and growing application. The problem can be cast as a planning problem under uncertainty. We describe the approach we have adopted to modelling and solving this problem, seen as a Markov Decision Problem, building effective policies for battery switching in the face of stochastic load profiles. Our solution exploits and adapts several existing techniques: planning for deterministic mixed discrete-continuous problems and Monte Carlo sampling for policy learning. The paper describes the development of planning techniques to allow solution of the non-linear continuous dynamic models capturing the battery behaviours. This approach depends on carefully handled discretisation of the temporal dimension. The construction of policies is performed using a classification approach and this idea offers opportunities for wider exploitation in other problems. The approach and its generality are described in the paper. Application of the approach leads to construction of policies that, in simulation, significantly outperform those that are currently in use and the best published solutions to the battery management problem. We achieve solutions that achieve more than 99% efficiency in simulation compared with the theoretical limit and do so with far fewer battery switches than existing policies. Behaviour of physical batteries does not exactly match the simulated models for many reasons, so to confirm that our theoretical results can lead to real measured improvements in performance we also conduct and report experiments using a physical test system. These results demonstrate that we can obtain 5%-15% improvement in lifetimes in the case of a two battery system.
